Technical Assistance Report
 
 
Project Number: 52239-001 
Knowledge and Support Technical Assistance (KSTA) 
December 2018 
 
 
 
 
Agricultural Value Chain Development in Selected 
Asian Countries 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
This document is being disclosed to the public in accordance with ADB's Public Communications 
Policy 2011.

ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  HLT  –  high-level technology 
  NRO  –  national research organization 
  SDCC  –  Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  Bambang Susantono, Knowledge Management and Sustainable 
Development 
Director General  WooChong Um, Sustainable Development and Climate Change 
Department (SDCC)

Operations 
  Hyunyoung Song, Natural Resources and Agriculture Specialist, 
Southeast Asia Department

of  or  reference  to  a  particular  territory  or  geographic  area  in  this  document,  the  Asian 
Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status of any 
territory or area.

ThisdocumentmustonlybegeneratedineOps. 13122018101924070359 Generated Date: 19-Dec-2018 14:46:28 PM

I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will identify the priority actions to 
be undertaken by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) and developing member countries (DMCs) 
to mobilize investments for improving market connectivity and value chain linkages, increasing 
agricultural productivity, and enhancing rural development. It will complement another TA which 
is currently assessing the investment requirements in the agriculture sector to end hunger and 
malnutrition in Asia and the Pacific; pilot climate-smart agriculture practices; and analyze ways to 
improve market connectivity by establishing modern wholesale markets.1 
 
2.  The TA supports the priorities articulated in ADB’s Strategy 2030,2 and ADB Management 
priorities to promote the use of high-level technology (HLT) in projects. The TA will contribute to 
ADB’s operational priorities in (i) accelerating progress in gender equality by building female 
farmers’ capacity, and (ii) promoting rural development and food security by increasing the 
agriculture profitability. The TA will also contribute to achieving Sustainable Development Goals.3 
The TA is included in the 2018–2019 work plan of the Rural Development and Food Security 
(Agriculture) Thematic Group (RDFS TG) and the 2018 results-based work plan of  ADB’s 
Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department (SDCC).4 
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
3.  Hunger is on the rise again in Asia and the Pacific. In 2016, almost 520 million people in 
Asia were living with food insecurity, up from 512 million in 2015. The region is one of the lowest-
rated regions in food security, only coming ahead of Sub-Saharan Africa.5 Asia and the Pacific 
ranks third in availability but fifth in affordability, indicating problems with supply and distribution 
chains. Considering these contexts, the food demand in Asia and the Pacific is expected to 
increase significantly with the increase in per capita income, middle-income consumers, and 
population growth.6 
 
4.  However, there are major challenges facing the production and distribution of food. The 
farm workforce is aging and decreasing, while climate change is now a formidable challenge.7 In 
future, fewer and older farmers, under the status quo, need to produce more food to feed the 
region’s growing population, underscoring the importance of the agricultural value and distribution 
chain. Farming must also be more profitable and farmers have to become “agripreneurs” to 
continue producing food while withstanding the emerging challenges. 
 
                                                           
1  ADB. 2016. Technical Assistance for Investment Assessment and Application of High-Level Technology for Food 
Security in Asia and the Pacific. Manila (TA 9218-REG). 
2  ADB. 2018. Strategy 2030: Achieving a Prosperous, Inclusive, Resilient, and Sustainable Asia and the Pacific. 
Manila. 
3  Sustainable Development Goals 1 (no poverty), 2 (zero hunger), and 12 (responsible production and consumption). 
4  The TA first appeared in the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 5 December 2018.  
5  The Economist Intelligence Unit. 2015. Global Food Security Index 2015. The Economist. 
6  Growth of gross domestic product in Asia and the Pacific is the highest among all regions, and the number of middle-
income consumers is projected to increase to about 3.5 billion by 2030 (The Brookings Institution 2017. The 
unprecedented expansion of the global middle class: An update. Washington DC) and the overall population is 
expected to increase to about 4.92 billion by 2030 (United Nations, Department of Economic and Social Affairs, 
Population Division (2015). World Population Prospects: The 2015 Revision, Key Findings and Advance Tables. 
Working Paper No. ESA/P/WP.241.) 
7  ADB. 2017. Safe, Nutritious, and Affordable Food for All: ADB Food Security Forum 2016 Discussions and 
Recommendations. Manila.

2 
5.  As many people still face starvation in DMCs, a significant portion of agricultural produce 
is  lost  during  post-harvest  processes.  The  preliminary  findings  of  the  TA  on  Investment 
Assessment and Application of High-Level Technology for Food Security in Asia and the Pacific 
(footnote 1) indicate that the value of avoidable post-harvest losses in Bangladesh, Nepal, 
Pakistan, and Viet Nam in one year is potentially higher than the investments required to develop 
modern agri-markets and agri-infrastructure to contain these losses in the long run. A number of 
factors hinder the development of modern agri-logistics and result in high post-harvest losses. 
Inappropriate public policy and institutions deter private financing for agri-logistics. Lack of 
production  and  marketing  information  and  slow  information  and  communication  technology 
adoption result in high supply chain losses. These factors imply the need for modern agri-logistics, 
technology-driven and knowledge-intensive production as well as post-production activities. 
 
6.  The main segments along the value chain where post-harvest losses occur need to be 
identified and analyzed. An analysis of the agricultural value chain using selected main vegetables 
to identify the core areas for intervention is needed to assess the potential increase in farmers’ 
profit due to reduced post-harvest losses. The findings will enable governments to realize the 
benefits of investing in agri-logistics and market infrastructure to improve the value chain. The 
findings, together with results of similar TA projects, will identify areas for private investment in 
the value chain, minimize post-harvest losses, improve profit distribution in favor of farmers, and 
improve food supply reliability. 
 
7.  Countries in Asia and the Pacific differ significantly in level of agriculture development. 
Farmers and policy makers from relatively lagging countries can learn from the experience of 
advanced  countries,  such  as  the  Republic  of  Korea,  in  promoting  technology-driven  and 
knowledge-intensive  agriculture  for  rural  development.  They  can  study  the  approaches  to 
agriculture and rural development by the Republic of Korea, which are globally acclaimed.8 
However, such study should consider the economic, social, and policy environment of DMCs like 
Indonesia, Myanmar, Pakistan, and the Philippines. The findings will provide insights to formulate 
country-specific recommendations through the application of HLT to replicate the Republic of 
Korea success. Development partners, the private sector, and other experts can also provide 
useful  insights  to  demonstrate  how  public–private  partnerships,  cofinancing,  and  social 
development initiatives can contribute to agriculture and rural development. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
8.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: agricultural profitability and rural development 
in participating DMCs enhanced.9 The TA will have the following outcome: investments in the 
modernization of agri-logistics and rural development increased.10 
 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
9.  The TA will support analytical work, study tours, and knowledge-dissemination activities 
in selected DMCs11 to identify the appropriate interventions to resolve the current problems that 
                                                           
8  https://www.adb.org/sites/default/files/publication/30380/ewp-363.pdf 
9 ADB. 2015. Operational Plan for Agriculture and Natural Resources: Promoting Sustainable Food Security in Asia 
and the Pacific in 2015–2020. Manila. 
10 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
11 In prioritizing DMCs for this TA, three factors will be used: (i) active agriculture and natural resources operations, 
both ongoing and pipeline; (ii) size of the economy; and (iii) growth in urbanization and middle-income consumers.

3 
 
hinder development of modern agri-logistics and affect value chain and rural development. It will 
support (i) estimation of post-harvest loss of selected main crops at different segments along the 
supply chain, (ii) analysis of the impact of existing post-harvest loss on profitability of agriculture 
and consumer price, (iii) study of approaches to agriculture and rural development and formulation 
of customized recommendations for agricultural value-chain and rural development for selected 
DMCs based on the experiences of the Republic of Korea, (iv) a study tour of men and women 
farmers and policy makers from selected DMCs to the Republic of Korea, and (v) dissemination 
of knowledge. 
  
10.  Output 1: Constraints on agricultural value chain development and main areas for 
investment improvement identified. Analysis of the agricultural supply chain using available 
macroeconomic data is ongoing in Bangladesh, Nepal, Pakistan, and Viet Nam under the TA on 
Investment Assessment and Application of High-Level Technology for Food Security in Asia and 
the Pacific. The focus of this analysis is how modern wholesale markets can potentially improve 
the efficiency of the agricultural value chain. Preliminary results, however, indicate several 
problems exist in the midstream and downstream activities—from harvesting to retailing. The TA 
will conduct a thorough analysis of the agricultural value chain from field to market in Indonesia, 
Myanmar, Pakistan, and the Philippines by using primary data with the help of country experts. 
The analysis will assess (i) the post-harvest loss occurring in different segments of the value chain 
such as harvesting, field stacking, cleaning, packaging, storage, transportation, and loading and 
unloading; (ii) farmer’s profitability; (iii) the number of intermediaries involved and their share in 
the consumer price; and (iv) the availability and quality of services like cold storage facilities, 
transportation, and packaging. The findings of these analyses will be reviewed internally and 
shared with country stakeholders before wider dissemination. Final findings will be used to initiate 
dialogue with the governments. 
 
11.  Output  2:  Country-specific  recommendations  for  agricultural  and  rural 
development based on the experiences of the Republic of Korea for selected DMCs 
formulated.  Analysis  of  the  Republic  of  Korea’s  experience  in  agriculture  modernization, 
horticulture value chains, and rural development will be carried out to draw lessons for selected 
DMCs.  A  consulting firm  with knowledge  on  the  Republic  of  Korea’s  agriculture  and  rural 
development,  as  well  as  familiarity  with  the  economic,  social,  and  policy  environments  of 
Indonesia, Myanmar, Pakistan, and the Philippines, will be engaged to implement this output. The 
analysis will include agri-logistics and infrastructure, storage facilities, and other HLT, including 
information and communication technology, and different rural development strategies used by 
the Republic of Korea to promote agricultural production and rural development. The analysis will 
provide country-specific recommendations for Indonesia, Myanmar, Pakistan, and the Philippines 
by taking their individual context into consideration to promote agriculture and rural development. 
The findings of the analysis will be internally reviewed for quality control before presentation at a 
knowledge-sharing  event.  Final  recommendations  will  be  shared  with  the  governments  of 
respective countries. 
 
12.  Output 3: Knowledge on agricultural value chain and rural development in selected 
DMCs improved. The TA will organize an international conference where policy makers, male 
and female farmers from the selected DMCs, development partners, private sector players, and 
experts will share experiences and exchange ideas to strengthen the agricultural value chains, 
build  new  physical  and  social  infrastructure to  minimize  post-harvest losses,  and  enhance 
agricultural production and rural development. Findings of outputs 1 and 2 will be used as inputs 
and/or discussion points in the conference. A study tour to the Republic of Korea will be organized 
to facilitate cross-country learning for at least three policy makers from the participating DMCs will 
participate.

4 
13.  Output 4: Knowledge on rural development, food security, and agriculture value 
chains in Asia and the Pacific improved. The TA will organize an international forum to enable 
experts,  policymakers,  researchers,  practitioners,  thinktanks,  and  representatives  from  key 
stakeholders to discuss global best practices, recent trends and innovations, and the use of 
information and communication technologies for improved rural development, market connectivity 
and agricultural value chains; increased agricultural productivity and food security; and enhanced 
food safety. The forum will help chart the strategic direction of rural development and food security 
as one of ADB’s operational priorities in Strategy 2030. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,700,000, of which (i) $500,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6) and (ii) $1,200,00012 will be financed 
on a grant basis by the Government of the Republic of Korea through the Ministry of Agriculture, 
Food and Rural Affairs and administered by ADB. The key expenditure items are listed in 
Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  The TA will be implemented over 3 years, from December 2018 to December 2021. ADB 
will administer the TA through the Agriculture, Rural Development and Food Security Unit (SDCC-
AR) of SDCC. SDCC-AR, which is also the secretariat of the RDFS TG, will be responsible for 
the overall supervision of the implementation. The secretariat will select, supervise, and evaluate 
consultants;  organize  workshops;  and  identify  resource  persons  in  the  conference  and 
workshops.  SDCC-AR  will  work  closely  with  relevant  operations  departments  and  resident 
missions on the study. 
 
16.  The implementation arrangements are summarized in the table. 
 
Implementation Arrangements 
Aspects  Arrangements 
Indicative implementation period  December 2018–December 2021 
Executing agency  Asian Development Bank 
Consultantsa  Firm: Fixed budget  National research  $440,000

country)

a  Output-based lump-sum contracts will be considered for consulting services for outputs 1 and 2. 
Source: Asian Development Bank. 
 
17.  Consulting services. ADB will engage consultants following the ADB Procurement Policy 
(2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated project administration instruction and/or 
staff instructions.13 
 
                                                           
12 The grant is subject to a 5% administrative fee. 
13 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).

5 
 
18.  For output 1, ADB will engage a reputable national research organization (NRO) with 
adequate research experience on agricultural value chains and marketing from each of the 
selected DMCs. Selected NROs will be engaged tentatively for 10 person-months (2.5 person-
months for each country) of international consultant services and 20 person-months (5 person-
months for each country) of national consultant services. 
 
19.  Output 2 will be implemented with the assistance of a consulting firm with knowledge of 
the agriculture sector and rural development in the Republic of Korea and familiarity with the 
economic, social, and policy environments of Indonesia, Myanmar, Pakistan, and the Philippines. 
The research organization will engage an estimated 3 person-months of international consultant 
services and 15 person-months of national consultant services. 
 
20.  The NROs and consulting firms will be engaged to deliver outputs 1 and 2 following the 
fixed budget selection method in accordance with the ADB Procurement Policy.  
  
21.  For output 3, ADB will recruit a national consultant with expertise in organizing knowledge 
events and study tours for 4 person-months following the individual consultant selection method. 
 
22.  For  output  4,  ADB  will  engage  three  international  consultants  for  5  person-months 
providing program design support and sector expertise; and three national consultants for 9 
person-months providing logistics, finance, and communications support for the international 
forum following the individual consultant selection method.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved (i) the 
Asian Development Bank (ADB) administering a portion of technical assistance not exceeding 
$1,200,000 to be financed on a grant basis by the Government of the Republic of Korea through 
the Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Rural Affairs and (ii) ADB providing the balance not 
exceeding  the  equivalent  of  $500,000  on  a  grant  basis  for  the  Agricultural  Value  Chain 
Development in Selected Asian Countries, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

Key Activities with Milestones 
 
1.   Constraints on agricultural value chain development and main areas for investment 
improvement identified 
1.1   Design the study for primary data collection to assess the post-production loss, farmers’ 
profitability, and share of different intermediaries in the consumer price of main vegetables in 
Indonesia, Myanmar, Pakistan, and the Philippines (Q1 2019–Q2 2019) 
1.2   Collect primary data on the selected vegetables (Q2 2019–Q3 2019) 
1.3   Analyze the post-production loss in terms of volumes and values of selected vegetables (Q3 
2019–Q1 2020) 
1.4   Assess the distribution of post-production loss among different stages of the supply chain (Q3 
2019–Q1 2020) 
1.5   Assess the profitability of farmers producing the selected vegetables (Q3 2019–Q1 2020) 
1.6   Estimate the share of different intermediaries in the consumer price of the selected vegetables 
(Q3 2019–Q1 2020) 
1.7   Disseminate the preliminary report for comments (Q2 2020) 
1.8  Incorporate the comments received on the preliminary report and finalize it (Q3 2020–Q4 2020)

8  Appendix 1 
Key Activities with Milestones 
 
1.9  Disseminate the final reports (Q2 2021) 
 
2.   Country-specific recommendations for agricultural and rural development based on the 
experiences of the Republic of Korea for selected DMCs formulated  
2.1   Review the agricultural transformation in the Republic of Korea to identify the main technologies 
and other factors that contributed to this transformation (Q1 2019–Q4 2019) 
2.2   Review the value chain development in the Republic of Korea to identify the main factors that 
contributed to this development (Q1 2019–Q4 2019) 
2.3   Review the rural development approaches and strategies of the Republic of Korea (Q1 2019–Q4 
2019) 
2.4   Review the available secondary reports and information on Indonesia, Myanmar, Pakistan, and 
the Philippines to assess the economic, social, and policy environment of these countries (Q1 
2019–Q4 2019) 
2.5   Formulate the country-specific recommendations for participating DMCs to promote agricultural 
transformation, value chain, and rural development based on the experiences of the Republic of 
Korea (Q4 2019–Q2 2020) 
2.6   Disseminate the preliminary reports for comments (Q3 2020) 
2.7   Incorporate the comments received and finalize the preliminary report (Q4 2020–Q1 2021) 
2.8   Disseminate the final reports (Q2 2021) 
 
3.   Knowledge on agricultural value chain and rural development in selected DMCs improved  
3.1  Organize a study tour for men and women farmers and government officials from the selected 
countries to the Republic of Korea (Q2 2020) 
3.2   Prepare a report summarizing the key features of the study tour, country workshops, and 
international conference (Q2 2021–Q3 2021) 
3.3   Organize an international conference on value chain development (Q3 2021) 
3.4   Prepare a report summarizing the key features of the study tour, country workshops, and 
international conference (Q3 2021–Q4 2021) 
 
4.    Knowledge on rural development, food security, and agriculture value chains in Asia and 
the Pacific improved  
4.1  Organize an international forum on rural development and food security (Q3 2019) 
4.2  Prepare a report summarizing the key features, insights, presentations and lessons learned (Q1 
2020)  
 
Inputs 
ADB: $0.5 million (TASF-6) 
Government of the Republic of Korea: $1.2 million 
 
Assumptions for Partner Financing 
Not applicable

technology, Q = quarter, RDFS TG = Rural Development and Food Security (Agriculture) Thematic Group, TA = 
technical assistance, TASF = Technical Assistance Special Fund.

Food Security in Asia and the Pacific in 2015–2020. Manila. 
Source: Asian Development Bank.

author_page:
ABBREVIATIONS 
 
  ADB  –  Asian Development Bank 
  DMC  –  developing member country 
  HLT  –  high-level technology 
  NRO  –  national research organization 
  SDCC  –  Sustainable Development and Climate Change Department 
  TA  –  technical assistance 
 
NOTE 
 
In this report, “$” refers to United States dollars. 
 
 
Vice-President  Bambang Susantono, Knowledge Management and Sustainable 
Development 
Director General  WooChong Um, Sustainable Development and Climate Change
